boost.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to increase or improve something and make it more successful
boost.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The new resort area has boosted tourism.
The win boosted the team’s confidence.
boost.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to help someone reach a higher place by lifting or pushing them
boost.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if a rocket or motor boosts a spacecraft, it makes it go up into space or go in a particular direction
boost.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: something that gives someone more confidence, or that helps something increase, improve, or become successful
boost.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Add a little more vanilla, to give the flavor a boost.
The community will get a boost from a new library and recreation center.
The poll provided a morale boost for the Conservatives.
a major boost to the economy
a multimillion-pound boost for the British film industry
boost.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: an increase in the amount of power available to a rocket, piece of electrical equipment etc
boost.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to increase something such as production, sales, or prices
boost.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The advertising campaign is intended to boost sales.
Another cut in interest rates would boost stock prices.
800 jobs have been cut in an attempt to boost productivity.
boost.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to make the economy stronger, so that business activity increases, prices and wages go up, and unemployment falls
boost.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The US Treasury ordered the Fed to lift the yen against the dollar in hopes of boosting the US economy before the November election.
boost.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The economy needs a positive jolt to boost consumer confidence.
boost.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: a special promotion to boost their new product
boost.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: something that helps to increase something such as production, sales, or prices
boost.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: That optimistic outlook gave stocks and the dollar a boost.
Sales could get a boost in January and February.
boost.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: something that helps something to improve or become more successful
boost.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The price of oil could soon be $15 a barrel or less, which would be a welcome boost to the American economy.
The sale of such a large nuclear power reactor is expected to give a boost to Canada’s nuclear industry.
The market got a boost on Friday when the Federal Reserve Board cut the interest rate that it charges member banks.
boost.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: something that helps to improve confidence or encourage people
boost.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: The end of the war would almost certainly provide some sort of boost to business and consumer confidence.
